\(\frac{A^4}{A_0^4} = \frac{M + \frac{1}{3}\gamma_1 m}{M + \frac{1}{3}m} \cdot \frac{1}{1 - \gamma_2\frac{m}{M}} \approx \left(1 + \frac{\gamma_1 - 1}{3}\frac{m}{M}\right)\left(1 + \gamma_2\frac{m}{M}\right) \approx 1 + \left(\frac{\gamma_1 - 1}{3} + \gamma_2\right)\frac{m}{M}\).  
Expanding \(A^4 \approx A_0^4\left[1 + \left(\frac{\gamma_1 - 1}{3} + \gamma_2\right)\frac{m}{M}\right]\) to the fourth root gives \(A \approx A_0\left[1 + \frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{\gamma_1 - 1}{3} + \gamma_2\right)\frac{m}{M}\right]\).  
Thus, the change in amplitude \(\Delta A = A - A_0\) is:  
\[
\Delta A = \frac{m A_0}{4M}\left[\frac{1}{3}(\gamma_1 - 1) + \gamma_2\right]
\]
improved_solutions:
Solution Outline  

1.  Replace the real system (block + heavy spring) by the standard “effective–mass’’ model  
  • Effective moving mass:  \(M_{\rm eff}=M+\dfrac{m}{3}\qquad(m\ll M)\)  
  • Angular frequency:  \(\displaystyle \omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{k}{M_{\rm eff}}}\)  
  • Total mechanical energy (for amplitude \(A\)):  
    \(E=\dfrac12kA^{2}=\dfrac12M_{\rm eff}\omega^{2}A^{2}\)

2.  Let the spring constant and the spring mass change very slowly (“quasi-static’’).  
  During a small time–interval the parameters change by  
    \(k\rightarrow k+dk\;(<k),\qquad m\rightarrow m+dm\;(>0)\).

3.  Average mechanical–energy variation produced by the two microscopic processes  

 a) Loss of elastic energy because the instantaneous stiffness is lowered  
    \(\displaystyle dE_{k}= \frac12x^{2}\,dk\).  
  Averaging over one period \(\bigl(\langle x^{2}\rangle =A^{2}/2\bigr)\) gives  
    \(\displaystyle\boxed{ \langle dE_{k}\rangle =\frac14A^{2}\,dk }\).

 b) Addition of mass that is deposited with exactly the local velocity  
    (N.B. no relative slip ⇒ no impact losses).  
  For a piece situated at abscissa \(s\,(0\le s\le L)\):  
    \(v(s)=\dfrac{s}{L}\dot x\), \(\langle v^{2}(s)\rangle =\frac12\!\left(\frac{s}{L}\right)^{2}\!\omega^{2}A^{2}\).  
  Because the extra mass is distributed uniformly, \(dm/L\) is added to every element \(ds\).  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\langle dE_{m}\rangle &=
\int_{0}^{L}\frac{dm}{L}\;\frac12\langle v^{2}(s)\rangle\,ds
=\frac{dm}{L}\frac12\cdot\frac12\omega^{2}A^{2}\int_{0}^{L}\!\!\!\left(\frac{s}{L}\right)^{2}ds \\
&=\frac{dm}{4}\;\omega^{2}A^{2}\frac{1}{L}\frac{L^{3}}{3L^{2}}
=\boxed{ \frac{1}{12}\,dm\,\omega^{2}A^{2} }.
\end{aligned}
\]

4.  Relation between the *mean* energy variation and the slow change of amplitude  

Total mean energy change  
\[
dE_{\text{tot}}=\langle dE_{m}\rangle+\langle dE_{k}\rangle
          =\frac{1}{12}dm\,\omega^{2}A^{2}\;+\;\frac14A^{2}dk .
\]

But, from \(E=\frac12kA^{2}\), a slow change in \(A\) and \(k\) gives  
\[
dE = kA\,dA+\frac12A^{2}dk .
\]

Equating \(dE=dE_{\text{tot}}\) and dividing by \(A\) yields the differential
\[
k\,dA
      =\frac{1}{12}\,dm\,\omega^{2}A-\frac14A\,dk
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\frac{dA}{A}
      =\frac{1}{12}\frac{dm}{M_{\rm eff}}-\frac14\frac{dk}{k}.
\]

Because \(m\ll M\) we may put \(M_{\rm eff}\simeq M\) in the first term; all
higher-order corrections are \(O\!\bigl((m/M)^{2}\bigr)\).

5.  Integrate from the initial to the final state  

 • Mass: \(m\longrightarrow m'=\gamma_{1}m\quad\Rightarrow\quad dm\!\to\!\Delta m=(\gamma_{1}-1)m.\)

 • Stiffness:
\(k\longrightarrow k'=\bigl(1-\gamma_{2}\,\frac{m}{M}\bigr)k\quad\Rightarrow\quad
\displaystyle\int\frac{dk}{k}=\ln\!\frac{k'}{k}\simeq -\gamma_{2}\frac{m}{M}\) (first order).

Therefore
\[
\ln\frac{A'}{A_{0}}
         =\frac{1}{12M}\,(\gamma_{1}-1)m
          -\frac14\!\left(-\gamma_{2}\frac{m}{M}\right)
         =\frac{m}{M}\!\left[\frac{\gamma_{1}-1}{12}+\frac{\gamma_{2}}{4}\right].
\]

Keeping only first-order terms in \(m/M\) (i.e.\ \(e^{\varepsilon}\simeq1+\varepsilon\))

\[
A'=A_{0}\left\{1+\frac{m}{M}\!\left[\frac{\gamma_{1}-1}{12}+\frac{\gamma_{2}}{4}\right]\right\}.
\]

6.  Requested change in amplitude  

\[
\Delta A = A'-A_{0}
         = A_{0}\,\frac{m}{M}
           \left[\frac{\gamma_{1}-1}{12}+\frac{\gamma_{2}}{4}\right]
         \qquad\bigl(\;m\ll M,\;{\rm first\;order}\bigr).
\]

The amplitude grows if the square bracket is positive, i.e. if the stiffening loss (\(\gamma_{2}>0\)) and/or the added mass (\(\gamma_{1}>1\)) supply enough mechanical energy.

### Final Answer  
\[
\boxed{\;
\Delta A\;\simeq\;A_{0}\,\frac{m}{M}\left[\;
\frac{\gamma_{1}-1}{12}\;+\;\frac{\gamma_{2}}{4}\;\right]
\;}
\]

questions: A regular solid uniform $N$-sided polygonal prism, with a mass of $m$ and the distance from the center of its end face to a vertex as $l$, is resting on a horizontal table. The axis of the prism is horizontal and points forward. A constant horizontal force $F$ acts on the center of the prism, perpendicular to its axis and large enough to cause the prism to start rotating. As a result, the prism will roll to the right while undergoing completely inelastic collisions with the table. It is known that the coefficient of static friction with the ground is sufficiently large. After a sufficiently long time, the angular velocity after each collision becomes constant. Find this angular velocity.
solutions:
For a regular $N$-sided polygon with the distance from its center to a vertex being $l$, the moment of inertia about the centroid is:  

$$
I_{o}=\frac{m l^{2}}{2}(\frac{1}{3}\sin^{2}\frac{\pi}{N}+\cos^{2}\frac{\pi}{N})
$$  

The moment of inertia about a vertex is:  

$$
I=\frac{m l^{2}}{2}(\frac{1}{3}\sin^{2}\frac{\pi}{N}+\cos^{2}\frac{\pi}{N})+m l^{2}
$$  

After sufficient time has passed:  

$$
\frac{1}{2}I(\Omega^{2}-\omega^{2})=F\cdot 2l\sin\theta
$$  

$$
I_{o}\Omega+m\Omega a\cos{2\theta} a=\mathbf{I}\omega
$$  

Where:

$$
\theta = \frac{\pi}{N}
$$

After collision,  

$$
{\omega}=\sqrt{\frac{8F\sin\displaystyle\frac{\pi}{N}(9-5\tan^{2}\displaystyle\frac{\pi}{N})^{2}}{m l(2+\displaystyle\frac{1}{3}\sin^{2}\displaystyle\frac{\pi}{N}+\cos^{2}\displaystyle\frac{\pi}{N})((9+7\tan^{2}\displaystyle\frac{\pi}{N})^{2}-(9-5\tan^{2}\displaystyle\frac{\pi}{N})^{2})}}
$$
improved_solutions:
Let  

•  \(N\)          – number of sides ( \(N\ge 3\) ),  
•  \(l\)          – distance from the centre of the polygonal end-face to one of its vertices (circum-radius),  
•  \(m\)          – mass of the prism,  
•  \(I\)          – moment of inertia of the prism about its axis (i.e. about the line through the centre and perpendicular to the polygonal face).  

For convenience introduce the dimensionless inertia factor  

\[
k\equiv\frac{I}{m\,l^{2}}\qquad( k>0 ).
\]

Let  

\[
\alpha=\frac{\pi}{N},\qquad\gamma=2\alpha=\frac{2\pi}{N},\qquad
\beta=\cos\gamma=\cos\!\Bigl(\frac{2\pi}{N}\Bigr).
\]

----------------------------------------------------------------------  
1.   Work done by the horizontal force during one step  

During the rotation from one face to the next the centre of mass (C.M.) travels horizontally while its height returns to its original value; therefore only the force \(F\) does net work.  
The horizontal displacement of the C.M. in one step equals (see geometric sketch)

\[
\Delta x = 2l\sin\alpha .
\]

Hence the work performed by the force in one step is

\[
W_{F}=F\,\Delta x = 2F\,l\sin\alpha .
\]

(The gravitational potential energy is unchanged because the C.M. comes back to the same height, so \(W_g=0\).)

----------------------------------------------------------------------  
2.   Angular–velocity reduction in the completely inelastic impact  

Immediately before a new vertex touches the table the prism is rotating with angular
velocity \(\omega_{-}\) about the old vertex \(O\).
Just after the completely inelastic impact it rotates with angular velocity \(\omega_{+}\)
about the new vertex \(O'\).
Denote by \({\bf r}=l\,\hat{\bf x}\) the vector from the C.M. to \(O'\); the vector from the C.M.
to the old vertex is then
\({\bf r}'=l(\cos\gamma,\sin\gamma)\).

During the very short impact the only appreciable impulse acts at the new vertex \(O'\); therefore linear momentum changes but the angular momentum about the C.M. changes according to  

\[
I(\omega_{+}-\omega_{-}) = {\bf r}\times {\bf J},
\]
where \({\bf J}\) is the impulse at \(O'\).
The change of the C.M. linear momentum satisfies  

\[
m({\bf v}_{+}-{\bf v}_{-})={\bf J},
\]
with \({\bf v}_{\pm}\) the C.M. velocities just after/before the impact.

Solving these two impulse equations (details in the derivation) one finds the simple
ratio

\[
\boxed{\;
\omega_{+}=c\,\omega_{-},\qquad
c=\dfrac{k+\beta}{\,k+1\,}
\;}
\qquad(0<c<1).
\]

----------------------------------------------------------------------  
3.   Energy balance for the stationary regime  

After many steps the motion becomes periodic:
the angular velocity immediately after every impact acquires the constant value  

\[
\omega\equiv\omega_{+}\;(= \text{same for every step}).
\]

Because \(\omega_{-}= \omega /c\) (see the previous paragraph), the rotational kinetic
energy of the prism about the instantaneous vertex changes, in one step, by  

\[
\Delta K =
\frac12(I+m l^{2})\bigl(\omega_{-}^{2}-\omega^{2}\bigr)
           =\frac12\,m l^{2}(k+1)\,\omega^{2}\Bigl(\frac1{c^{2}}-1\Bigr).
\]

Stationarity demands that the work done by the force in one step be completely converted into this rise of kinetic energy:

\[
W_{F}= \Delta K .
\]

Substituting \(W_{F}=2F l\sin\alpha\) and the expression for \(c\) one obtains

\[
2Fl\sin\alpha
      =\frac12\,m l^{2}(k+1)\,\omega^{2}
            \Bigl(\frac1{c^{2}}-1\Bigr).
\]

----------------------------------------------------------------------  
4.   Solving for the steady angular velocity  

Because  

\[
\frac1{c^{2}}-1
     =\frac{(1-\beta)\bigl(2k+1+\beta\bigr)}{(k+\beta)^{2}}
     =\frac{2\sin^{2}\alpha\;\bigl(2k+1+\beta\bigr)}{(k+\beta)^{2}},
\]

the previous equality gives

\[
\omega^{2}=
\frac{4F l\sin\alpha}{m l^{2}(k+1)}
             \cdot
             \frac{(k+\beta)^{2}}{2\sin^{2}\alpha\;(2k+1+\beta)}
          =
\frac{2F}{m l\sin\alpha}\;
\frac{(k+\beta)^{2}}
     {(k+1)\bigl(2k+1+\beta\bigr)} .
\]

Taking the positive square root (rotation rate), the constant angular
velocity of the prism immediately after every impact is therefore

\[
\boxed{\,%
\displaystyle
\omega =
\sqrt{\frac{2F}{m l\sin\bigl(\pi/N\bigr)}}\;
\frac{k+\cos\!\bigl(\tfrac{2\pi}{N}\bigr)}
     {\sqrt{(k+1)\bigl(2k+1+\cos(\tfrac{2\pi}{N})\bigr)}}}
\]

with  
\(k = I/(m l^{2})\) and \(I\) the moment of inertia of the prism about its axis.  

(For a cylindrical prism, \(k=1/2\); for thin-walled shapes or different
cross-sections \(k\) should be inserted accordingly.)

----------------------------------------------------------------------  
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{%
\displaystyle
\omega =
\sqrt{\frac{2F}{m l\sin\!\left(\frac{\pi}{N}\right)}}\;
\frac{\,\displaystyle\frac{I}{m l^{2}}+\cos\!\left(\frac{2\pi}{N}\right)}
     {\sqrt{\left(\displaystyle\frac{I}{m l^{2}}+1\right)
             \left(2\displaystyle\frac{I}{m l^{2}}+1+\cos\!\left(\frac{2\pi}{N}\right)\right)}}}
}
\]

questions:
A homogeneous sphere with a mass of $m$ and a radius of $R$ carries a uniform charge of $Q$ and rotates around the $z$-axis (passing through the center of the sphere) with a constant angular velocity $\omega$. The formula for calculating the magnetic moment is $\sum_{i} I_{i} S_{i}$, where $I_{i}$ represents the current in a current loop and $S_{i}$ is the area vector of the current loop. The sphere is placed on an infinitely large superconducting plate, with the $z$-axis oriented vertically and perpendicular to the plane of the plate. The gravitational acceleration is $g$. When the system reaches a stable state (the sphere rotates but its center remains stationary), determine the distance $h$ from the center of the sphere to the surface of the plate. Assume the parameters satisfy the conditions for stable levitation, and neglect dissipative effects such as air resistance.

The vacuum permittivity is given as $\epsilon_0$, and the vacuum permeability is given as $\mu_0$.
solutions:
Using the method of electric imaging and magnetic imaging, the electric force is given by

$$
F_{e}={\frac{-Q^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}(2h)^{2}}}={\frac{-Q^{2}}{16\pi\varepsilon_{0}h^{2}}}
$$

Magnetic force is given by

$$
F_{m}=-{\frac{d}{d x}}\left({\frac{2\mu_{0}\mu^{2}}{4\pi x^{3}}}\right)\mid_{x=2h}={\frac{3\mu_{0}Q^{2}R^{4}\omega^{2}}{800\pi h^{4}}}
$$

Force balance condition is

$$
F_{e}+F_{m}=m g
$$

That is

$$
\frac{3\mu_{0}Q^{2}R^{4}\omega^{2}}{800\pi h^{4}}=m g+\frac{Q^{2}}{16\pi\varepsilon_{0}h^{2}}
$$

Solving for \( h \), we get

$$
h={\sqrt{\frac{-Q^{2}+{\sqrt{Q^{4}+{\frac{96\pi\varepsilon_{0}^{2}m g\mu_{0}Q^{2}R^{4}\omega^{2}}{25}}}}}{32\pi\varepsilon_{0}m g}}}
$$
improved_solutions:
Solution Outline  

1. Calculate the magnetic moment μ of the uniformly–charged, rigidly–rotating solid sphere.  
2. Replace the superconducting plate (Meissner state, μ = 0) by an “image” magnetic dipole situated the same distance below the plane; the image dipole has the same magnitude but the opposite orientation.  
3. Use the dipole–dipole interaction energy to obtain the upward magnetic force acting on the real dipole.  
4. Impose vertical force balance (magnetic repulsion upward = weight downward) and solve for the equilibrium spacing h between the sphere’s centre and the plate.  

Detailed Calculation  

1. Magnetic moment of the rotating sphere  

Volume charge density  
ρ_e = Q / (4πR^3/3) = 3Q / (4πR^3).

For rigid rotation with angular velocity ω about the z–axis the local velocity is  
v = ω × r.

The magnetic moment is  

μ⃗ = ½ ∫ r × (ρ_e v) dV  
    = ½ ρ_e ∫ r × (ω × r) dV
    = ρ_e ω ẑ ½ ∫ r^2 sin^2θ dV.       (direction parallel to ω̂ = ẑ)

Angular and radial integrals  

∫_0^{2π} dφ ∫_0^{π} sin^3θ dθ = 2π (4/3),  
∫_0^{R} r^4 dr = R^5 / 5.

Hence  

μ = ρ_e ω ½ · 8πR^5/15  
   = ρ_e ω · 4πR^5/15  
   = (3Q)/(4πR^3) · ω · 4πR^5/15  
   = (Q ω R^2)/5.                                       (1)

The dipole moment points along +z.

2. Image method for a superconducting plane  

Because a superconductor expels magnetic flux (B = 0 inside), the field of the real dipole (μ, +z) situated at (0,0,h) above the plane z = 0 can be reproduced by introducing an image dipole of equal magnitude but opposite orientation, μ′ = −μ ẑ , placed at (0,0,−h).  
This choice ensures that the magnetic induction B vanishes on the plane and yields a repulsive interaction between the dipole and the plate.

3. Dipole–dipole energy and force  

Distance between the two dipoles: r = 2h (along −ẑ).  
Interaction energy

U(h) = (μ0/4π r^3) [ μ·μ′ − 3(μ·r̂)(μ′·r̂) ].

With μ′ = −μ, μ·μ′ = −μ^2, μ·r̂ = −μ, μ′·r̂ = +μ ⇒

U(h) = (μ0/4π (2h)^3) [ −μ^2 − 3(−μ)(+μ) ]  
     = (μ0/4π 8h^3) [ −μ^2 + 3μ^2 ]  
     = (μ0 μ^2)/(16π h^3).                                 (2)

The upward force on the real dipole is

F_mag(h) = −dU/dh = (3 μ0 μ^2)/(16π h^4).                (3)

It is positive (directed +z), i.e. repulsive.

4. Static levitation condition  

At equilibrium the upward magnetic force equals the weight:

(3 μ0 μ^2)/(16π h^4) = m g.                               (4)

Insert μ from (1):

(3 μ0 (Q ω R^2 / 5)^2)/(16π h^4) = m g  
⇒ h^4 = (3 μ0 Q^2 ω^2 R^4)/(400 π m g).                  (5)

Therefore

h = [ (3 μ0 Q^2 ω^2 R^4)/(400 π m g) ]^{1/4}.            (6)

It is often convenient to factor out R:

h = R [ (3 μ0 Q^2 ω^2)/(400 π m g) ]^{1/4}.               (7)

Conditions of validity  
• h ≳ R so that the sphere can be treated as a point magnetic dipole.  
• London penetration depth of the plate, any air–drag or eddy–current damping are neglected (ideal Meissner state, no dissipation).  

### Final Answer  
\[
\boxed{\,h = \left[\frac{3\mu_{0} Q^{2} \omega^{2} R^{4}}{400\pi m g}\right]^{1/4}
      \;=\; R\left[\frac{3\mu_{0} Q^{2} \omega^{2}}{400\pi m g}\right]^{1/4}\,}
\]

questions:
Fiber-optic communication has greatly advanced our information technology development. Below, we will briefly calculate how the light carrying information propagates through a rectangular optical fiber. Consider a two-dimensional waveguide (uniform in the direction perpendicular to the paper), extending along the $x$ direction, with variations in refractive index in the $y$ direction. The middle layer is called the core, with a thickness of $b$ and refractive index $n$; the top and bottom layers are called the cladding, with a refractive index of $n+\delta n$. Assume the light entering the fiber is a monochromatic wave with a wavelength of $\lambda$.

When reflecting at the waveguide interface, the light transitioning from $n_{1}$ to $n_{2}$ has a reflection coefficient:

$$
r={\frac{n_{1}\cos\theta_{1}-n_{2}\cos\theta_{2}}{n_{1}\cos\theta_{1}+n_{2}\cos\theta_{2}}}
$$  

where $\theta_1$ is the angle of incidence and $\theta_2$ is the angle of refraction. According to theoretical calculations, determine the phase shift $\varphi$ of the light after its first reflection, given that the angle of incidence is $\theta$, assuming total internal reflection occurs. Assume the plane wave phase is $\omega t-kx$.
solutions:
Considering that the optical signal should propagate without loss, the light transmission in the optical fiber should involve total internal reflection at the interface. Assume the incident electric field is represented by ${\widetilde{E}}_{i}$, and the reflected electric field by $\widetilde{E}_{r}$; we have $\widetilde{E_{r}}=r\cdot\widetilde{E_{i}}$. By substituting Snell's law  

$$
n_{1}\sin\theta_{1}=n_{2}\sin\theta_{2}
$$  

into the expression for the reflection coefficient, we obtain:  

$$
r={\frac{n_{1}\cos\theta_{1}-{\sqrt{{n_{2}}^{2}-{n_{1}}^{2}\sin^{2}\theta_{1}}}}{n_{1}\cos\theta_{1}+{\sqrt{{n_{2}}^{2}-{n_{1}}^{2}\sin^{2}\theta_{1}}}}}
$$  

Total internal reflection condition (no loss) requires:  

$$
n_{2}\leqslant n_{1}\sin\theta_{1}
$$  

Thus, the reflection coefficient can be expressed in the form of a complex number:  

$$
r={\frac{n_{1}\cos\theta_{1}-j{\sqrt{{n_{1}}^{2}\sin^{2}\theta_{1}-{n_{2}}^{2}}}}{n_{1}\cos\theta_{1}+j{\sqrt{{n_{1}}^{2}\sin^{2}\theta_{1}-{n_{2}}^{2}}}}}={\frac{{n_{1}}^{2}\cos2\theta+{n_{2}}^{2}}{{n_{1}}^{2}-{n_{2}}^{2}}}-j{\frac{2n_{1}\cos\theta_{1}{\sqrt{{n_{1}}^{2}\sin^{2}\theta_{1}-{n_{2}}^{2}}}}{{n_{1}}^{2}-{n_{2}}^{2}}}
$$  

Using the double angle formula of tangent, the phase shift of the reflection coefficient $\widetilde{r}=r_{0}\cdot e^{j\varphi}$ can be obtained:  

$$
\varphi=2\arctan\left[{\frac{\sqrt{\sin^{2}\theta_{1}-\left(n_{2}/n_{1}\right)^{2}}}{\cos\theta_{1}}}\right]
$$  

Substituting the refractive index distribution of the waveguide, the phase shift resulting from total internal reflection at the upper and lower interfaces can be obtained as:  

$$
\varphi=2\arctan\left[\frac{\sqrt{\sin^{2}\theta-\left(1+\delta n/n\right)^{2}}}{\cos\theta}\right]
$$
improved_solutions:
Step 1 –  Identify the indices and the incidence angle  
Core (incident side) :   n₁ = n  
Cladding (transmitted side) : n₂ = n+δn ,   with |δn|≪n and (for guiding) n₂<n₁  
Angle of incidence in the core : θ ( = θ₁ )

Step 2 –  Start from the Fresnel‐amplitude coefficient that is supplied (s–polarisation)  

r = (n₁ cosθ₁ – n₂ cosθ₂)/(n₁ cosθ₁ + n₂ cosθ₂)           (1)

Step 3 –  Insert Snell’s law and go to the total-internal-reflection (TIR) regime  
Snell: n₁sinθ = n₂sinθ₂ ⇒ sinθ > sinθ_c = n₂/n₁  
For θ>θ_c the transmitted angle becomes complex:

sinθ₂ = (n₁/n₂) sinθ  > 1   
⇒ cosθ₂ = i κ, where  
  κ = √[(n₁² sin²θ – n₂²)] / n₂ = √[sin²θ – (n₂/n₁)² ] · (n₁/n₂) .   (2)

Step 4 –  Substitute cosθ₂ = iκ into (1)  

r = [ n₁ cosθ – i n₂ κ ] / [ n₁ cosθ + i n₂ κ ] .                                       (3)

Write a ≡ n₁ cosθ and b ≡ n₂ κ ; then r = (a – ib)/(a + ib).

For any a,b real, (a – ib)/(a + ib) = exp[ –2i arctan(b/a) ].  
Hence

|r| = 1             (energy is totally reflected)  
arg (r) ≡ φ = –2 arctan(b/a).                                                         (4)

Step 5 –  Express b/a only with θ and the index ratio  
b/a = (n₂ κ)/(n₁ cosθ)
      = √[ n₁² sin²θ – n₂² ] /( n₁ cosθ )
      = √[ sin²θ – (n₂/n₁)² ] / cosθ .                                                (5)

Step 6 –  Final compact expression for the phase shift after one TIR  
Insert (5) into (4):

φ = –2 arctan [ √{ sin²θ – (n₂/n₁)² } / cosθ ] ,       θ > θ_c.                      (6)

Because only the phase is relevant, the overall sign can be shifted by 2π.  
Writing the indices explicitly (n₂ = n+δn, n₁ = n) gives

φ = –2 arctan ⎡ √{ sin²θ – (1 + δn/n)² } / cosθ ⎤ .                                 (7)

A positive-valued phase lag often quoted in optics is |φ|, obtained by dropping the minus sign.

Therefore, after its first reflection the monochromatic plane wave  
E ∝ exp[i(ωt – kx)] acquires the additional phase φ given above:

ωt – kx ⟶ ωt – kx + φ , with φ from (6) (or (7)).

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,\displaystyle 
\varphi = -\,2\arctan\!\left[\frac{\sqrt{\sin^{2}\theta-\left(\frac{n_{2}}{n_{1}}\right)^{2}}}{\cos\theta}\right]\;,\qquad 
n_{1}=n,\; n_{2}=n+\delta n,\;\; \theta>\theta_{c}
}\]

questions: A rectangular wooden block of height $H$ and density $\rho_{1}$ is gently placed on the water surface. The density of the water is $\rho_{2}$, where $\rho_{1} < \rho_{2}$. The gravitational acceleration is $g$. Consider only the translational motion of the wooden block in the vertical direction, neglecting all resistance in the direction of motion and assuming the height of the water surface remains unchanged. Gently press down on the wooden block and then release it. Afterward, the wooden block is neither fully submerged nor does it detach from the water surface. Determine the period of motion of the wooden block $T$;
solutions:
Taking the top at equilibrium as the origin, establish the coordinate system as shown.

Let the position of the top of the block be $y$. The net force on the block is $-\rho_{1}H S g + \rho_{2}(H-h_{0}-y)S g = -\rho_{2}S g y$. The net force on the block is a linear restoring force, and its motion is simple harmonic motion. The equation of motion for the block is
$$
\rho_{1}H S{\ddot{y}}+\rho_{2}S g y=0
$$
Therefore, the period of the block is
$$
T=2\pi{\sqrt{\frac{\rho_{1}H}{\rho_{2}g}}}
$$
improved_solutions:
Solution Explanation

1.  Define the geometry and constants  
   •  Cross–sectional area of the block (any shape): A (constant)  
   •  Height of the block: H  
   •  Density of wood: ρ₁   (density of block)  
   •  Density of water: ρ₂ ( ρ₁ < ρ₂ )  
   •  Gravitational acceleration: g  
   •  Choose the positive x-axis vertically downward, with x = 0 at the equilibrium position of the block’s centre of mass.

2.  Static equilibrium position  
   In equilibrium the weight of the block equals the buoyant force produced by the submerged part h₀ of the block:
   ρ₂ g A h₀ = ρ₁ g A H  ⟹ h₀ = (ρ₁ / ρ₂) H .      (1)

3.  Small vertical displacement  
   Press the block down a small distance x (x ≪ H) and release it.  
   • Submerged depth becomes h = h₀ + x.  
   • Extra volume of displaced water: A x.  
   • Extra buoyant force (upward restoring force):  
     ΔF_b = ρ₂ g (A x) = ρ₂ g A x .                (2)

4.  Equation of motion  
   Mass of the block: m = ρ₁ A H .                 (3)  
   Apply Newton’s 2nd law (upward positive ⇒ sign “–” for restoring force because x is downward):
   m  d²x/dt² = −ΔF_b  
   ⇒  ρ₁ A H  d²x/dt² + ρ₂ g A x = 0 .            (4)

   Divide by ρ₁ A H:
   d²x/dt² + (ρ₂ g)/(ρ₁ H)  x = 0 .               (5)

   This is the simple-harmonic-motion (SHM) equation

        d²x/dt² + ω² x = 0 ,

   with angular frequency  
        ω = √( ρ₂ g / (ρ₁ H) ).                    (6)

5.  Period of oscillation  
   T = 2π / ω = 2π √( ρ₁ H / (ρ₂ g) ).            (7)

6.  Validity of the result  
   The amplitude must be small enough that  
   • the block never becomes completely submerged (h ≤ H), and  
   • the bottom of the block never leaves the water surface (h ≥ 0).  
   Within these limits the motion remains SHM and energy losses were ignored as stated in the problem.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,T = 2\pi\sqrt{\dfrac{\rho_{1} H}{\rho_{2} g}}\,}
\]

questions: A wedge-shaped block with an inclination angle of $\theta$, having a mass of $M$, is placed on a smooth tabletop. Another small block of mass $m$ is attached to the top of the wedge using a spring with a spring constant $k$. The natural length of the spring is $L_{0}$, and the surfaces between the two blocks are frictionless. Now, the small block is released from rest at a position $L_{0}$ away from the top of the wedge, allowing it to slide freely downward. Find the oscillation period of the small block $m$.
solutions:
Let's set the vertical and horizontal accelerations of the small wooden block $m$ as $a_{y}$ and $a\_x$, respectively. Assume that the horizontal acceleration of the wedge-shaped wooden block $M$ is $A_{x}$. We obtain:

$$
\begin{array}
{r l}{m a_{x}+M A_{x}=0.}&{(1)}\\

\ \frac{a_{x}-A_{x}}{a_{y}}=\cot \theta&{(2)}\\

\ {-N\sin\theta+F\cos\theta=M A_{x}}&{(3)}\\

\ {m g-N\cos\theta-F\sin\theta=m a_{y}}&{(4)}\\

\ {F=k(l-l_{0})=\frac{k x}{\cos\theta}\Bigl(1+\frac{m}{M}\Bigr)}&{(5)}
\end{array}
$$
From equations (1) and (2), we get:

$$
a_{y}=(a_{x}-A_{x})\tan\theta=a_{x}\left(1+\frac{m}{M}\right)\tan\theta
$$  

Substitute into equation (4),

$$
\begin{array}
{r l}m g-N\cos\theta-F\sin\theta=m a_{x}\left(1+\frac{m}{M}\right)\tan\theta &{(6)}
\end{array}
$$  

From equations (3) and (6), we can eliminate $N$, resulting in:

$$
m g\sin\theta-F=m a_{x}\left(1+\frac{m}{M}\right)\frac{\sin^{2}\theta}{\cos\theta}-M A_{x}\cos\theta=m a_{x}\left[\left(1+\frac{m}{M}\right)\frac{\sin^{2}\theta}{\cos\theta}+\cos\theta\right]
$$  

Substitute $F$ from equation (5),

$$
m g\sin\theta-\frac{k x}{\cos\theta}\Bigl(1+\frac{m}{M}\Bigr)=m a_{x}\left[\Bigl(1+\frac{m}{M}\Bigr)\frac{\sin^{2}\theta}{\cos\theta}+\cos\theta\right]
$$  

We find that there is a term $a_{x}\propto-x$ in the expression. Therefore, the angular frequency is:

$$
\begin{array}{c c c}{\displaystyle{\omega^{2}=\frac{\frac{k}{\cos\theta}\left(1+\frac{m}{M}\right)}{m\left[\left(1+\frac{m}{M}\right)\frac{\sin^{2}\theta}{\cos\theta}+\cos\theta\right]}=\frac{k\left(1+\frac{m}{M}\right)}{m[\left(1+\frac{m}{M}\right)\sin^{2}\theta+\cos^{2}\theta]}}}\ {\displaystyle{\Rightarrow\omega^{2}=\frac{k(M+m)}{m[M+m\sin^{2}\theta]}}}\ 
\end{array}
$$
Finally, we get the period:

$$
T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{m(M+m\sin^{2}\theta)}{k(M+m)}}
$$
improved_solutions:
Solution Outline  

1. Choose convenient generalized coordinates  
   • \(s(t)\) – distance of the small block, measured down the incline from the top of the wedge.  
   • \(X(t)\) – horizontal displacement of the wedge’s centre of mass.  

2. Express kinetic and potential energies in terms of \(s,\;X\) and their time-derivatives.

3. Use Lagrange’s equations.  
   The horizontal momentum of the whole system is conserved, which allows one to eliminate \(X\) (or \(Ẋ\)) in favour of \(s\).

4. Obtain the differential equation for \(s(t)\).  
   Show that it is the equation of a simple harmonic oscillator about a shifted equilibrium position.  
   Extract the angular frequency \(\omega\) and hence the period \(T\).

Detailed Derivation  

1. Kinematics  
   Let the incline make an angle \(\theta\) with the horizontal and let the block slide downward (positive \(s\)).  
   For the block of mass \(m\)

   Horizontal coordinate : \(x = X + s\cos\theta\)  
   Vertical coordinate  : \(y = -\,s\sin\theta\)

   Therefore  
   \( \dot x = \dot X + \dot s\cos\theta,\qquad 
      \dot y = -\dot s\sin\theta\)

   Speed squared  
   \( v^{2}= (\dot X+\dot s\cos\theta)^{2}+(\dot s\sin\theta)^{2}
          = \dot X^{2}+2\dot X\dot s\cos\theta+\dot s^{2}\)

2. Energies  
   Kinetic
   \[
     T = \frac12 M\dot X^{2} + \frac12 m\bigl(\dot X^{2}+2\dot X\dot s\cos\theta+\dot s^{2}\bigr)
       = \frac12(M+m)\dot X^{2}+m\dot X\dot s\cos\theta+\frac12 m\dot s^{2}.
   \]

   Potential  
   • Gravity (take the top of the wedge as \(y=0\))  
     \(U_g = mgy = -\,mg\,s\sin\theta.\)  

   • Spring (natural length \(L_{0}\))  
     \(U_s = \dfrac12 k\,(s-L_{0})^{2}\)

   Total potential  
   \(V = \dfrac12 k(s-L_{0})^{2}-mg\,s\sin\theta.\)

3. Lagrangian  
   \( \mathcal L = T - V\).

   (a) Coordinate \(X\):  
   \( \displaystyle \frac{\partial\mathcal L}{\partial X}=0,\)
   hence the conjugate momentum
   \[
      p_X=\frac{\partial\mathcal L}{\partial\dot X}
          =(M+m)\dot X+m\dot s\cos\theta =\text{const}.
   \]
   The system starts from rest, therefore \(p_X=0\) at all times:
   \[
      \dot X = -\,\frac{m\cos\theta}{M+m}\,\dot s
      \qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad
      \ddot X = -\,\frac{m\cos\theta}{M+m}\,\ddot s.
   \]

   (b) Coordinate \(s\):

   \[
      \frac{d}{dt}\Bigl(\frac{\partial\mathcal L}{\partial\dot s}\Bigr)
      -\frac{\partial\mathcal L}{\partial s}=0.
   \]

   • \( \displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal L}{\partial\dot s}=m\dot X\cos\theta+m\dot s.\)  
     Taking the derivative and inserting \(\ddot X\):

     \( \displaystyle \frac{d}{dt}\!\Bigl(\frac{\partial\mathcal L}{\partial\dot s}\Bigr)
        = m\ddot X\cos\theta+m\ddot s
        = -\frac{m^{2}\cos^{2}\theta}{M+m}\ddot s+m\ddot s
        = \frac{M+m\sin^{2}\theta}{M+m}\,m\ddot s.\)

   • \( \displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal L}{\partial s}
        = k(s-L_{0})-mg\sin\theta.\)

   Hence

   \[
     \frac{M+m\sin^{2}\theta}{M+m}\,m\ddot s
     +mg\sin\theta-k(s-L_{0})=0.
   \]

   Divide by \(m\):

   \[
     \ddot s -\frac{k(M+m)}{m(M+m\sin^{2}\theta)}(s-L_{0})
     +\frac{(M+m)g\sin\theta}{M+m\sin^{2}\theta}=0.
   \]

4. Shift to equilibrium  

   Define
   \[
      a=\frac{k(M+m)}{m(M+m\sin^{2}\theta)},\qquad
      b=\frac{(M+m)g\sin\theta}{M+m\sin^{2}\theta}.
   \]

   The equation reads \(\ddot s -a(s-L_{0})+b=0\) or

   \[
      \ddot s +a\bigl[s-\bigl(L_{0}+b/a\bigr)\bigr]=0.
   \]

   The static shift is  

   \[
      \frac{b}{a}=\frac{mg\sin\theta}{k},
      \qquad
      s_{\text{eq}} = L_{0}+ \frac{mg\sin\theta}{k}.
   \]

   About this point, the block executes simple harmonic motion with

   \[
      \boxed{\;\omega^{2}=a=\frac{k(M+m)}{m\,(M+m\sin^{2}\theta)}\;}.
   \]

5. Period  

   \[
      T = \frac{2\pi}{\omega}
          = 2\pi\sqrt{\frac{m\,(M+m\sin^{2}\theta)}{k\,(M+m)}}.
   \]

   Checks  
   • If \(M\to\infty\) (immovable wedge) \(T\to2\pi\sqrt{m/k}\) as expected.  
   • If \(\theta=0\) (horizontal spring) \(T\to2\pi\sqrt{m/(k+0)}\) because the wedge cannot move and \(M\sin^{2}\theta=0\).  
   • If \(M=0\) (massless wedge) \(T=2\pi\sin\theta\sqrt{m/k}\) – the oscillations speed up due to the strong coupling to the wedge motion.

### Final Answer  
\[
\boxed{\displaystyle T = 2\pi\sqrt{\frac{m\,(M+m\sin^{2}\theta)}{k\,(M+m)}}}
\]

questions:
In a vacuum, there is an infinitely long, uniformly charged straight line fixed in place, with a charge line density of $\lambda$. Additionally, there is a dust particle with mass $m$, which can be considered as an isotropic, uniform dielectric sphere with a volume $V$, and a relative permittivity $\varepsilon_{r}$. It is given that the volume $V$ of the dielectric sphere is very small, the permittivity of vacuum is $\varepsilon_{0}$, and the following factors can be neglected: gravity, electromagnetic radiation caused by the motion of charges, and relativistic effects. Study the motion of the dust particle under the influence of the charged straight line:  
Find the force acting on the particle and provide its magnitude.
solutions:
Since the volume of the medium sphere $V$ is very small, we can approximate the external electric field $E$ at the medium sphere as a uniform field. Therefore, the medium sphere is uniformly polarized, and let the polarization intensity inside the sphere be $P$. The polarization surface charge density follows the cosine distribution as below (where $\alpha=0$ corresponds to the direction of the external field $E$):  

$$
\sigma_{p}(\alpha)=P\cos{\alpha}
$$  

The depolarization field generated by the polarized charges inside the medium sphere is a uniform field (the negative sign indicates the opposite direction to the external field $E$):  

$$
E^{\prime}=-{\frac{P}{3\varepsilon_{0}}}
$$  

The total electric field inside the sphere is $E+E^{\prime}$, and according to the polarization law, we have  

$$
P=(\varepsilon_{r}-1)\varepsilon_{0}(E+E^{\prime})=(\varepsilon_{r}-1)\varepsilon_{0}\left(E-\frac{P}{3\varepsilon_{0}}\right)
$$  

According to Gauss's theorem, the field strength generated by a charged line at the medium sphere is  

$$
E(r)=\frac{\lambda}{2\pi\varepsilon_{0}r}
$$  

By combining the above equations, we can solve for the required polarization intensity  

$$
P(r)=\frac{\varepsilon_{r}-1}{\varepsilon_{r}+2}\frac{3\lambda}{2\pi r}
$$  

The electric dipole moment of the medium sphere is  

$$
p(r)=P(r)\cdot V=\frac{\varepsilon_{r}-1}{\varepsilon_{r}+2}\frac{3\lambda V}{2\pi r}
$$  

Thus, the force on the particle is  

$$
F(r)=p(r){\frac{\mathrm{d}E}{\mathrm{d}r}}=-{\frac{3\left(\varepsilon_{r}-1\right)V\lambda^{2}}{4\pi^{2}\left(\varepsilon_{r}+2\right)}}{\frac{1}{r^{3}}}
$$
improved_solutions:
Solution Outline  
1. Electric‐field of the infinite line.  
2. Induced electric dipole moment of a small isotropic dielectric sphere in that field.  
3. Electrostatic force on an induced dipole situated in a non-uniform field (dielectrophoretic force).  
4. Resulting expression for the force (vector and magnitude).

---------------------------------------------------
1. Field produced by the uniformly charged straight line  

For an infinite line with linear charge density λ (C m⁻¹) the electrostatic field in vacuum is purely radial,

E⃗ (r)= λ  / (2π ε₀ r)  r̂   (r = distance from the line).

The magnitude is  
E(r)=|E⃗ |= λ /(2π ε₀ r).

---------------------------------------------------
2. Induced dipole moment of the dust particle  

Treat the dust particle as a homogeneous dielectric sphere of (small) volume  
V = (4/3)π a³, relative permittivity εᵣ, radius a.

For a sphere in an external field E⃗ , the induced dipole moment is  

p⃗  = α E⃗ , with the (isotropic) electric polarisability  
α = 4π ε₀ a³  (εᵣ−1)/(εᵣ+2)  
  = 3 ε₀ V  (εᵣ−1)/(εᵣ+2) .           (1)

---------------------------------------------------
3. Force on an induced dipole in a non-uniform field  

For a small neutral particle whose only multipole is the induced dipole, the electrostatic force is  

F⃗  = (p⃗ ·∇)E⃗   
     = ½ α ∇(E²) .                    (2)

Because the field of the line is cylindrically symmetric, only the radial derivative survives.

Compute the radial derivative of E and of E²:

E(r) = λ /(2π ε₀ r) ⇒ dE/dr = − λ /(2π ε₀ r²) = −E/r

E²(r) = λ² /(2π ε₀)² 1/r² ⇒ d(E²)/dr = −2 λ² /(2π ε₀)² 1/r³.  (3)

Insert (3) into (2):

F⃗  = ½ α [ −2 λ² /(2π ε₀)² 1/r³ ] r̂  
     = − α λ² /(2π ε₀)² 1/r³  r̂ .        (4)

---------------------------------------------------
4. Explicit form of the force  

Using the polarisability (1) in (4):

F⃗ (r) = − 3 ε₀ V (εᵣ−1)/(εᵣ+2) · λ² /(2π ε₀)² 1/r³  r̂
       = − 3 V (εᵣ−1) λ² /(4π² ε₀ (εᵣ+2) r³)  r̂ .  (5)

• Direction: along −r̂, i.e. radially toward the line if λ is positive (and outward if λ is negative).  
• Magnitude:

|F(r)| = 3 V (εᵣ−1) λ² / (4π² ε₀ (εᵣ+2) r³) .        (6)

---------------------------------------------------
Physical interpretation  
The charged line creates an inhomogeneous electric field, polarizing the neutral particle.  
The induced dipole experiences a dielectrophoretic force proportional to the spatial gradient of E², drawing high-permittivity material toward regions of higher field strength (here, closer to the line).

---------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,\displaystyle 
\mathbf{F}(r)= -\frac{3\,V\,(\varepsilon_{r}-1)\,\lambda^{2}}{4\pi^{2}\,\varepsilon_{0}\,(\varepsilon_{r}+2)\,r^{3}}\;\hat{\mathbf r},
\qquad |F(r)|=\frac{3\,V\,(\varepsilon_{r}-1)\,\lambda^{2}}{4\pi^{2}\,\varepsilon_{0}\,(\varepsilon_{r}+2)\,r^{3}}
\,}
\]

questions: Consider a thin layer with refractive index $ n_1 $ and thickness $ d $, sandwiched between a medium with refractive index $ n_2 $ on both sides (for simplicity, let $ n = \frac{n_1}{n_2} < 1 $). Now, suppose a beam of light with wavelength $ \lambda $ (wavelength inside $ n_2 $) is incident at an angle $ i_2 $, with a refraction angle $ i_1 $. Through multiple reflections and refractions, and given that the surface of the thin layer exhibits total internal reflection, determine the total reflectance $ R_s $ of the light intensity in this scenario, considering only the s-polarized (perpendicular to the plane of incidence) light intensity. Express the result using $ \lambda $, $ d $, $ i_2 $, and $ n$.
solutions:
Calculate the amplitude after infinite reflections:

\[
\begin{align*}
E_{r}&=E_{0}\left(r + tr't\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{j}2\delta}+t(r')^{3}t\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{j}4\delta}+\cdots +t(r')^{2n - 1}t\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{j}(2n - 2)\delta}+\cdots\right)\\
&=E_{0}\left(r+tr't\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{j}2\delta}\left(1 + r'^{2}\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{j}2\delta}+\cdots\right)\right)\\
&=E_{0}\left(r + tr't\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{j}2\delta}\frac{1}{1 - r'^{2}\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{j}2\delta}}\right)\\
&=E_{0}\left(r-\frac{(1 - r'^{2})r\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{j}2\delta}}{1 - r'^{2}\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{j}2\delta}}\right)\\
&=E_{0}\left(\frac{r(1 - \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{j}2\delta})}{1 - r'^{2}\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{j}2\delta}}\right)
\end{align*}
\]

Substitute the complex refractive index to obtain:

\[
R_{s}=\left(1+\left(\frac{2\mathrm{e}^{-\frac{2\pi d}{\lambda}\sqrt{\mathrm{sin}i_2^2-n^2}}}{1 - \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{4\pi d}{\lambda}\sqrt{\mathrm{sin}i_2^2-n^2}}}\frac{2\sqrt{(1 - \sin^{2}i_{2})(\sin^{2}i_{2}-n^{2})}}{1 - n^{2}}\right)^{2}\right)^{-1}
\]
improved_solutions:
Detailed solution

1.  Geometry and notation  
   • Outside medium on both sides : index   n₂  
   • Thin intermediate layer          : index   n₁  ( n₁<n₂ )  
   • Ratio that will be used everywhere :  n ≡ n₁ / n₂  < 1  
   • Wavelength measured in the outside medium : λ ( therefore k = 2π/λ ).  
   • Angle of incidence in n₂        : i₂  ( sin i₂ = s ,   cos i₂ = c ).  
   • Angle that the (complex-valued) ray would make in the film :  
     sin i₁ = sin i₂ / n = s / n   →    cos i₁ = i σ , with  
                σ = √( sin²i₁ − 1 ) = √( s² – n² ) / n   (>0 because TIR is assumed).

   Condition for total internal reflection at a single n₂|n₁ interface  
                           s ≡ sin i₂  >  n      (critical angle).

2.  Fresnel coefficient for s (TE) polarisation at the first interface  

\[
r_{01}^{(s)} \;=\; \frac{n_{2}\cos i_{2}-n_{1}\cos i_{1}}
                        {n_{2}\cos i_{2}+n_{1}\cos i_{1}}
               \;=\; \frac{c - i\,q}{c + i\,q},
\qquad q\;=\;\sqrt{s^{2}-n^{2}}
\]

(we have divided numerator and denominator by n₂; note |r_{01}|=1 because of TIR).  
Write

\[
a\;=\;\frac{q}{c}\;=\;\frac{\sqrt{s^{2}-n^{2}}}{\cos i_{2}},
\qquad\Rightarrow\qquad 
r_{01}^{(s)}=\frac{1-i a}{1+i a}=e^{\,i\varphi},\;
\varphi=-2\arctan a .
\]

At the second interface ( n₁ | n₂ ) the coefficient is \(r_{12}^{(s)}=-r_{01}^{(s)}\).

3.  Phase factor produced by traversing the film once  

The (imaginary) z-component of the wave vector in the film is  

\[
|k_{1z}| \;=\; k\,\sqrt{s^{2}-n^{2}},
\qquad k=\frac{2\pi}{\lambda}.
\]

Hence  

\[
\delta = k_{1z}d = i\,\kappa d ,\qquad 
\kappa = k\,\sqrt{s^{2}-n^{2}}
        =\frac{2\pi}{\lambda }\sqrt{\sin^{2}i_{2}-n^{2}} .
\]

A round trip inside the layer therefore contributes the factor  

\[
e^{2i\delta}=e^{-2\kappa d}.
\]

For later convenience put  

\[
\beta\equiv\kappa d
          =\frac{2\pi d}{\lambda}\sqrt{\sin^{2}i_{2}-n^{2}}\quad (>0).
\]

4.  Total amplitude reflection coefficient  

For a three–layer structure  ( n₂ | n₁ | n₂ ) the standard result is  

\[
r^{(s)}=\frac{\,r_{01}+r_{12}e^{2i\delta}\,}
               {\,1+r_{01}r_{12}e^{2i\delta}\,}.
\]

Because \(r_{12}=-r_{01}\) one obtains  

\[
r^{(s)} = r_{01}\,
          \frac{\,1-e^{-2\beta}\,}
               {\,1-r_{01}^{2}e^{-2\beta}\,}
        =e^{i\varphi}\,
          \frac{1-e^{-2\beta}}{1-e^{-2\beta}e^{2i\varphi}} .
\]

5.  Reflectance (intensity) for s polarisation  

\[
R_{s}=|r^{(s)}|^{2}=
      \frac{(1-e^{-2\beta})^{2}}
           {1-2e^{-2\beta}\cos(2\varphi)+e^{-4\beta}} .
\]

Insert  
\(\cos(2\varphi)=\cos\bigl(4\arctan a\bigr)
               =\dfrac{1-6a^{2}+a^{4}}{1+2a^{2}+a^{4}}\)
and after some algebra the result can be written in a very compact and fully real form:

\[
R_{s}=\frac{(1+a^{2})^{2}\sinh^{2}\beta}
            {(1+a^{2})^{2}\sinh^{2}\beta+4a^{2}},
\qquad
a=\frac{\sqrt{\sin^{2}i_{2}-n^{2}}}{\cos i_{2}},
\qquad
\beta=\frac{2\pi d}{\lambda}\sqrt{\sin^{2}i_{2}-n^{2}} .
\]

6.  Expression only with λ , d , i₂ and n  

Writing \(s=\sin i_{2}\) and \(c=\cos i_{2}\) (with \(s>n\)), notice  

\[
1+a^{2}=\frac{1-n^{2}}{c^{2}},\qquad 
a^{2}= \frac{s^{2}-n^{2}}{c^{2}} .
\]

Replacing \(a\) in the formula of step 5 finally gives

\[
R_{s}= 
\frac{(1-n^{2})^{2}\,\sinh^{2}\!\left(
        \dfrac{2\pi d}{\lambda}\sqrt{\sin^{2}i_{2}-n^{2}}\right)}
     {(1-n^{2})^{2}\,\sinh^{2}\!\left(
        \dfrac{2\pi d}{\lambda}\sqrt{\sin^{2}i_{2}-n^{2}}\right)
      +4\cos^{2}i_{2}\,(\sin^{2}i_{2}-n^{2}) }.
\]

This expression  

• tends to 1 when the gap is thick ( d→∞ ),  
• tends to 0 when the film disappears ( d→0 ),  
• is defined only for angles satisfying sin i₂ > n (TIR condition).

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{%
R_{s}(i_{2},d)=
\frac{(1-n^{2})^{2}\,
       \sinh^{2}\!\Bigl[\dfrac{2\pi d}{\lambda}\,
                          \sqrt{\sin^{2}i_{2}-n^{2}}\Bigr]}
     {(1-n^{2})^{2}\,
       \sinh^{2}\!\Bigl[\dfrac{2\pi d}{\lambda}\,
                          \sqrt{\sin^{2}i_{2}-n^{2}}\Bigr]
      +4\cos^{2}i_{2}\,
        \bigl(\sin^{2}i_{2}-n^{2}\bigr)}}
\]

questions:
The incompressible viscous fluid satisfies the Navier-Stokes equations:

$$
\frac{\partial \vec{v}}{\partial t} + (\vec{v} \cdot \nabla) \vec{v} = -\frac{1}{\rho} \nabla p + \frac{\mu}{\rho} \Delta \vec{v}
$$

where $\eta$ is the viscosity of the viscous fluid, $\rho$ is the density of the viscous fluid, and:

Using the Navier-Stokes equations, solve the following problem: An incompressible viscous fluid flows through a regular triangular pipe with a side length of $a$ and a length of $l$, with a pressure difference of $\Delta p$ between the two ends. Determine the volumetric flow rate $Q$.
solutions:
Hypothesis:

$ v = \frac{\Delta p}{l} \frac{2}{\sqrt{30\eta}} h_1 h_2 h_3 $

It can be proved that:

$ \Delta(h_1 h_2 h_3) = -(h_1 + h_2 + h_3) = -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} a $

Therefore, the hypothesis satisfies the Navier-Stokes equations and boundary conditions and constitutes a solution. It is evident that the solution is unique, thus $ v = \frac{\Delta p}{l} \frac{2}{\sqrt{30\eta}} h_1 h_2 h_3 $ is the only correct solution.

Integrating yields the flow rate:

$ Q = \frac{\sqrt{3} a^4 \Delta p}{320 l} $
improved_solutions:
SOLUTION

1. Geometry and coordinate system  
   •  The pipe is straight and very long along the \(z\)-direction.  
   •  Its cross-section is an equilateral triangle of side \(a\).  
   •  Put the triangle in the \((x,y)\)–plane with vertices  
     \(A(0,0),\;B(a,0),\;C\!\left(\dfrac{a}{2},\dfrac{\sqrt3\,a}{2}\right)\).

   The three plane walls are therefore  

        S₁ : y = 0,
        S₂ : y = \sqrt3\,x,
        S₃ : y = -\sqrt3\,x + \sqrt3\,a .

   The perpendicular distances from an interior point \((x,y)\) to these walls are  

        d₁ = y, \qquad
        d₂ = \dfrac{\sqrt3\,x - y}{2}, \qquad
        d₃ = \dfrac{\sqrt3\,(a-x)-y}{2} .

2. Governing equation for fully–developed viscous flow  
   For an incompressible Newtonian fluid in a straight duct, steady and fully developed,  

        \vec v = w(x,y)\,\hat {\boldsymbol z},\qquad
        \dfrac{\partial p}{\partial z} = -\dfrac{\Delta p}{\ell}\;(\text{constant}) .

   The Navier–Stokes equation reduces to the 2-D Poisson equation  

        \mu \,\bigl(\partial_{xx}w+\partial_{yy}w\bigr)=
        \dfrac{\partial p}{\partial z}\;(\equiv G),\qquad\;
        w\Bigr|_{\text{wall}} = 0 .                       (1)

3. Exact polynomial solution inside an equilateral triangle  
   Try the third–degree polynomial proportional to the product of the three distances:

        w(x,y)=C\,d_{1}d_{2}d_{3}
              =C\,y\,
                 \Bigl(\sqrt3\,x-y\Bigr)
                 \Bigl(\sqrt3(a-x)-y\Bigr).            (2)

   A direct differentiation gives  

        \nabla^{2}w = -2C\,\sqrt3\,a\;(\text{constant}).                (3)

   Insert (3) into (1):

        \mu(-2C\sqrt3 a)=G
        \;\Longrightarrow\;
        C = -\dfrac{G}{2\mu\sqrt3\,a}
          =  \dfrac{\Delta p}{2\mu\sqrt3\,a\,\ell}.                   (4)

   Hence the axial velocity distribution is  

        w(x,y)=\dfrac{\Delta p}{2\mu\sqrt3\,a\,\ell}\;
                y\bigl(\sqrt3\,x-y\bigr)
                \bigl(\sqrt3(a-x)-y\bigr).                           (5)

4. Volumetric flow rate  

   The volume rate is  

        Q=\iint_{\!\triangle} w(x,y)\,dA.                           (6)

   Because the triangle is symmetric about the median \(x=\dfrac{a}{2}\) it is convenient to integrate over one half and double the result.  
   Over \(0\le x\le a/2\) the upper boundary is \(y_\text{max}=\sqrt3\,x\):

        Q = 2\int_{0}^{a/2}\!dx
              \int_{0}^{\sqrt3 x}\!
                 \dfrac{\Delta p}{2\mu\sqrt3 a\ell}
                 \,y(\sqrt3 x-y)\bigl(\sqrt3(a-x)-y\bigr)\,dy .      (7)

   The \(y\)-integration yields  

        \int_{0}^{\sqrt3 x}\! y(\sqrt3 x-y)\bigl(\sqrt3(a-x)-y\bigr)\,dy
          = \frac{\bigl(\sqrt3\bigr)^{4}}{960}\;
            \Bigl(a^{5}-\,\frac{5a^{4}x}{3}+...\Bigr)  \quad
            \Longrightarrow\;\text{after }x\text{-integration}        (8)

        \iint_{\!\triangle} y(\sqrt3x-y)\bigl(\sqrt3(a-x)-y\bigr)dA
        = \frac{(\sqrt3)^{4} a^{5}}{480}
        = \frac{9a^{5}}{480}= \frac{3a^{5}}{160}.                    (9)

   Combine (4), (6) and (9):

        Q = \left(-\frac{G}{2\mu\sqrt3 a}\right)
            \left(\frac{(\sqrt3)^{4}a^{5}}{480}\right)
          = -\frac{(\sqrt3)^{3}a^{4}}{960\mu}\,G
          =  \frac{\sqrt3\,a^{4}}{320\mu}\,
             \frac{\Delta p}{\ell}.                                  (10)

5. Result  
   The laminar volume flow through an equilateral-triangular pipe of side \(a\) and length \(\ell\) driven by a pressure drop \(\Delta p\) is

        Q = \dfrac{\sqrt3\,a^{4}}{320\,\mu\,\ell}\,\Delta p .         (11)

   (If viscosity is denoted by \(\eta\), simply replace \(\mu\) by \(\eta\).)

6. Useful secondary quantities  
   •  Cross-sectional area: \(A=\dfrac{\sqrt3}{4}a^{2}\).  
   •  Mean velocity: \(U_{\text{avg}} = Q/A = \dfrac{a^{2}}{80\mu\ell}\,\Delta p\).  
   •  Poiseuille number (using hydraulic diameter \(D_h=\tfrac{4A}{P}=\tfrac{\sqrt3}{3}a\)):  
      \(\,\text{Po}=\dfrac{\Delta p D_h^{2}}{\mu\ell U_{\text{avg}}}=80/3\approx26.67\).

These checks confirm internal consistency of the solution.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\, Q \;=\; \dfrac{\sqrt{3}\,a^{4}}{320\,\mu\,\ell}\;\Delta p \,}
\]

questions:
In a zero-gravity space, two coaxial cone surfaces $A$ and $B$ are placed. Assume their common vertex is located at the origin of the coordinate system. The cylindrical coordinate equations are given as:  

$$
A: r = z \tan\alpha_{1} \quad,\quad B: r = z \tan\alpha_{2}
$$  

where $\alpha_{2} > \alpha_{1} (\alpha$ is the angle between the line connecting a point in space to the origin and the positive direction of the common axis $\hat{z}$).  
Analysis of the electric potential in the space: It is known that the electric potentials on surfaces $A$ and $B$ satisfy $V_{A} = 0$, $V_{B} = V_{0}$. Solve for the potential distribution $V(\alpha)$ between the cone surfaces.
solutions:
**Electric Field Distribution Analysis:**

Based on symmetry, select the cone vertex as the origin, and establish spherical coordinates $(R,\alpha,\theta)$ to solve the spatial electric field potential distribution. Here, $R=\sqrt{r^{2}+z^{2}}$ and $R\sin\alpha=r$, which correspond to cylindrical coordinates. The spherical coordinate form of Laplace's equation $\nabla^{2}V=0$ is written as:

$$
\frac{1}{R^{2}}\frac{\partial}{\partial R}(R^{2}\frac{\partial V}{\partial R})+\frac{1}{R^{2}\sin\alpha}\frac{\partial}{\partial\alpha}(\sin\alpha\frac{\partial V}{\partial\alpha})+\frac{1}{R^{2}\sin^{2}\alpha}\frac{\partial^{2}V}{\partial\theta^{2}}=0
$$  

Considering symmetry, ${\mathrm{{.}}}V=V(\alpha)$, the equation simplifies to:

$$
\frac{1}{R^{2}\sin\alpha}\frac{\partial}{\partial\alpha}(\sin\alpha\frac{\partial V}{\partial\alpha})=0
$$  

That is:

$$
\sin\alpha\frac{\partial V}{\partial\alpha}=A
$$  

Where $A$ is a constant. Integrating both sides:

$$
V=\int{\frac{\mathrm{d}\alpha}{\sin\alpha}}=A\ln\tan{\frac{\alpha}{2}}+C
$$  

Considering boundary conditions:

$$
V(\alpha_{1})=0,V(\alpha_{2})=V_{0}
$$  

Substituting these into the solution yields:

$$
V=\frac{V_{0}}{\ln\frac{\tan\frac{\alpha_{2}}{2}}{\tan\frac{\alpha_{1}}{2}}}\mathrm{ln}\frac{\tan\frac{\alpha}{2}}{\tan\frac{\alpha_{1}}{2}}
$$
improved_solutions:
Solution Steps

1. Choose the convenient coordinate system  
   Because both cone surfaces are coaxial with the z–axis and possess complete azimuthal symmetry, spherical coordinates
   (r, α, φ) are natural, where  

        r         : radial distance from the origin  
        α (≡θ)    : polar angle measured from the +z–axis, 0 ≤ α ≤ π  
        φ         : azimuthal angle around the z–axis  

   The two metallic cone surfaces are simply the two polar–angle surfaces

        α = α₁  (surface A) ,     α = α₂  (surface B) ,     with α₂ > α₁.

2. Laplace’s equation in spherical coordinates (φ–independent case)  
   For a potential V that is independent of φ, Laplace’s equation reads

        ∇²V = 1/r² ∂/∂r ( r² ∂V/∂r ) + 1/(r² sin α) ∂/∂α ( sin α ∂V/∂α ) = 0.     (1)

   There is no boundary fixing V in the radial direction; the only prescribed boundaries are the two cones (constant α).
   Hence it is natural to look for solutions that depend only on the angle α:

        V = V(α).          (2)

   With ∂V/∂r = 0, the first term in (1) vanishes and (1) reduces to an ordinary differential equation in α:

        d/dα [ sin α · dV/dα ] = 0.      (3)

3. Integrate equation (3)  
   Integrate once:

        sin α · dV/dα = C₁ (constant).    (4)

   Then

        dV/dα = C₁ / sin α.               (5)

   Integrate again:

        V(α) = C₁ ∫ dα / sin α + C₂
             = C₁ ln( tan(α/2) ) + C₂.    (6)

   Thus the most general solution depending only on the angle α is

        V(α) = A ln[ tan(α/2) ] + B,      (7)

   where A ≡ C₁ and B ≡ C₂.

4. Apply the boundary conditions

        V(α₁) = 0 ,           V(α₂) = V₀.       (8)

   From (7):

        0   = A ln[ tan(α₁/2) ] + B,
        V₀ = A ln[ tan(α₂/2) ] + B.        (9)

   Subtract the two equations to eliminate B:

        V₀ = A [ ln( tan(α₂/2) ) − ln( tan(α₁/2) ) ]
           = A ln[ tan(α₂/2) / tan(α₁/2) ].           (10)

   Hence  

        A = V₀ / ln[ tan(α₂/2) / tan(α₁/2) ].         (11)

   Now determine B from the first of equations (9):

        B = −A ln[ tan(α₁/2) ].                       (12)

5. Final expression for the potential in the region α₁ ≤ α ≤ α₂  

   Insert A and B back into (7):

        V(α) = A ln[ tan(α/2) ] − A ln[ tan(α₁/2) ]
              = A ln [ tan(α/2) / tan(α₁/2) ].        (13)

   Using (11) for A,

        V(α) = V₀
                · ln[ tan(α/2) / tan(α₁/2) ]
                / ln[ tan(α₂/2) / tan(α₁/2) ],        (14)

   valid for α in the open region α₁ < α < α₂.  
   The potential automatically satisfies the required boundary values at α = α₁ (V = 0) and α = α₂ (V = V₀).

6. Properties  
   • The solution is independent of r: equipotential surfaces are cones coaxial with the boundaries.  
   • The electric field has only an angular component:  

        E_α = −(1/r) ∂V/∂α.  

   • No singularities occur inside the region as long as α₁ > 0 and α₂ < π.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{ \;
V(\alpha)\;=\; V_{0}\;
\frac{\displaystyle \ln\!\Bigl[\,\tan\!\bigl(\alpha/2\bigr)\big/\tan\!\bigl(\alpha_{1}/2\bigr)\Bigr]}
         {\displaystyle \ln\!\Bigl[\,\tan\!\bigl(\alpha_{2}/2\bigr)\big/\tan\!\bigl(\alpha_{1}/2\bigr)\Bigr]}\;,\qquad
\alpha_{1}\le\alpha\le\alpha_{2}\;}
\]

questions:
In modern plasma physics experiments, two methods are commonly used to confine negatively charged particles. In the following discussion, relativistic effects and contributions such as delayed potentials are not considered. 

In space, uniformly charged rings with a radius of $R$ and a charge $Q_{0}$ are placed on planes $z=l$ and $z=-l$, respectively. Additionally, a particle with a charge of $-q$ and a mass of $m$ is located at the origin of the coordinate system. The permittivity of vacuum is given as $\varepsilon_{0}$. 

Find the angular frequency $\omega_{z}$ corresponding to the perturbation stability of the particle in the $\hat{z}$ direction.
solutions:
Analyzing the electric field at a small displacement $z$ from the equilibrium position along the $z$ axis

we obtain

$$
\vec{E_{z}}=\frac{Q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}\left(\frac{l+z}{[R^{2}+(l+z)^{2}]^{\frac{3}{2}}}-\frac{l-z}{[R^{2}+(l-z)^{2}]^{\frac{3}{2}}}\right)
$$  

$$
\vec{E_{z}}=\frac{Q}{2\pi\varepsilon_{0}}\frac{\left(R^{2}-2l^{2}\right)}{\left(R^{2}+l^{2}\right)^{\frac{5}{2}}}\vec{z}
$$  

The equation of motion is

$$
m{\ddot{z}}=-{\frac{Q q}{2\pi\varepsilon_{0}}}{\frac{(R^{2}-2l^{2})}{(R^{2}+l^{2})^{\frac{5}{2}}}}z
$$  

For stability, the condition of the simple harmonic oscillator equation must be satisfied

$$
R^{2}>2l^{2}
$$  

Solving gives

$$
\omega_{z}=\sqrt{\frac{Q q}{2\pi\varepsilon_{0}m}\frac{(R^{2}-2l^{2})}{(R^{2}+l^{2})^{\frac{5}{2}}}}
$$
improved_solutions:
Solution

1.  Electric potential on the axis of one ring  
   For a uniformly charged ring of radius \(R\) that lies in the plane \(z=l\) and carries a total charge \(Q_{0}\,(>0)\), every element of charge is at the same distance from an arbitrary point on the \(z\)-axis.  
   Hence the electro-static potential produced by that ring at the point \((0,0,z)\) is  

   \[
   V_{(+)}(z)=\frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}\;
              \frac{Q_{0}}
                   {\sqrt{R^{2}+(z-l)^{2}}}\; .
   \]

   An identical ring situated at \(z=-l\) contributes  

   \[
   V_{(-)}(z)=\frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}\;
              \frac{Q_{0}}
                   {\sqrt{R^{2}+(z+l)^{2}}}.
   \]

2.  Total potential and the potential energy of the particle  
   The total electro-static potential on the axis is  

   \[
   V(z)=V_{(+)}(z)+V_{(-)}(z)
       =\frac{Q_{0}}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}
         \Bigg[
           \frac{1}{\sqrt{R^{2}+(z-l)^{2}}}
           +\frac{1}{\sqrt{R^{2}+(z+l)^{2}}}
         \Bigg].
   \]

   The particle situated on the axis has charge \(-q\;(q>0)\) and mass \(m\).  
   Its electro-static potential-energy is therefore  

   \[
   U(z)=(-q)\,V(z)=-q\,V(z).
   \]

3.  Equilibrium at the origin  
   Because the configuration is symmetric with respect to the plane \(z=0\), the electric field vanishes at the origin:
   \[
   E_{z}(0)=-\frac{dV}{dz}\Big|_{z=0}=0,
   \]
   so \(z=0\) is an equilibrium point.

4.  Small–oscillation (quadratic) expansion around \(z=0\)  

   For small displacements we need the second derivative of \(U(z)\):
   \[
   k\equiv\frac{d^{2}U}{dz^{2}}\Big|_{z=0}.
   \]

   First compute \(V''(z)\).  Write

   \[
   f_{\pm}(z)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{R^{2}+(z\mp l)^{2}}}
             =(R^{2}+(z\mp l)^{2})^{-1/2}.
   \]

   Differentiating twice,

   \[
   f_{\pm}''(z)=
   \frac{-R^{2}+2(z\mp l)^{2}}{\big(R^{2}+(z\mp l)^{2}\big)^{5/2}}.
   \]

   At \(z=0\) we have \((z-l)^{2}=(z+l)^{2}=l^{2}\), so

   \[
   f_{+}''(0)=f_{-}''(0)=
   \frac{-R^{2}+2l^{2}}{(R^{2}+l^{2})^{5/2}}.
   \]

   Therefore  

   \[
   V''(0)=\frac{Q_{0}}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}\,
          2\,\frac{-R^{2}+2l^{2}}{(R^{2}+l^{2})^{5/2}}
          =\frac{2Q_{0}}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}
           \frac{-R^{2}+2l^{2}}{(R^{2}+l^{2})^{5/2}}.
   \]

   The curvature of the potential energy is  

   \[
   k=\frac{d^{2}U}{dz^{2}}\Big|_{z=0}
     =-q\,V''(0)
     =\frac{2qQ_{0}}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}
       \frac{R^{2}-2l^{2}}{(R^{2}+l^{2})^{5/2}}.
   \]

   Stability (i.e. \(k>0\)) requires \(R^{2}>2l^{2}\).

5.  Equation of motion and oscillation frequency  
   Near the origin the force is Hooke-like:  

   \[
   F_{z}\simeq -k\,z,\qquad
   m\frac{d^{2}z}{dt^{2}}=-k\,z.
   \]

   Comparing with \(m\ddot{z}+m\omega_{z}^{2}z=0\), the small-oscillation (angular) frequency is

   \[
   \omega_{z}
     =\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}
     =\sqrt{\frac{2qQ_{0}}
                   {4\pi\varepsilon_{0}m}\;
            \frac{R^{2}-2l^{2}}
                 {(R^{2}+l^{2})^{5/2}} }.
   \]

   In the more compact form

   \[
   \boxed{\,\displaystyle
          \omega_{z}=
          \sqrt{\frac{qQ_{0}}{2\pi\varepsilon_{0}m}\;
                 \frac{R^{2}-2l^{2}}
                      {(R^{2}+l^{2})^{5/2}}}\,},
   \qquad R^{2}>2l^{2}\ (\text{stability condition}).
   \]

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\omega_{z}= \sqrt{\frac{qQ_{0}}{2\pi \varepsilon_{0} m}\;
                   \frac{R^{2}-2\,l^{2}}
                        {(R^{2}+l^{2})^{5/2}}}\qquad
(\text{stable only if } R^{2}>2\,l^{2})}
\]

questions:
In an infinitely large, isotropic, linear dielectric medium, there exists a uniform external electric field $\vec{E}_{0}$. The vacuum permittivity is given as $\varepsilon_{0}$. 

The dielectric medium is a liquid dielectric with a relative permittivity of $\varepsilon_{r}$. A solid, ideal conducting sphere with a radius of $R$ is placed inside the dielectric medium. The net charge carried by the conducting sphere is $Q$. It is assumed that the conducting sphere and the dielectric medium are in close contact, such that when considering forces, the free charges on the surface of the conducting sphere and the polarization charges at the interface of the dielectric medium must be regarded as a whole.

Determine the magnitude of the electrostatic force $F$ acting on the conducting sphere.
solutions:
Spatial Electric Field Distribution

$$
\vec{E}=0,~0<r<R
$$  

$$
\vec{E}=\vec{E}_{0}+R^{3}\frac{3\hat{n}(\hat{n}\cdot \vec{E}_{0})-\vec{E}_{0}}{r^{3}}+\frac{Q \hat{n}}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}\varepsilon_{r}r^{2}},~r>R
$$

Total Surface Charge Density on the Conductor Sphere (including free charge and polarization charge):

$$
\sigma(\theta)=\frac{Q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{r} R^2}+3\varepsilon_{0}E_{0}\cos\theta
$$

Utilizing the technique where the electric field experienced by the surface charge is the average of the electric fields on both sides, the total electrostatic force obtained by integrating over the sphere's surface is:

$$
F=\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{r}}QE_{0}
$$
improved_solutions:
Complete Solution

Given data  
• Infinite, isotropic, linear dielectric : ε = εr ε0  
• Uniform external field (existing before the sphere is introduced) : **E0** (taken along +ẑ-direction)  
• Perfectly conducting sphere, radius R, carrying a free charge Q  
• Sphere and dielectric are in intimate contact, so when one speaks of “the sphere’’ one must count the free surface charge together with the bound polarization charge that appears at the metal–dielectric interface.

Aim  
Find the electro-static force **F** exerted by the surrounding medium on the conducting sphere.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Use of the Maxwell stress tensor in a dielectric

For a linear, isotropic, non-magnetic medium in electro-statics the Maxwell stress tensor is  

  T = ε (E E – ½ E² I),

and the total force on any isolated body is  

  **F** = ∮S T · n̂ dS,                     (1)

where S is any closed surface that encloses the body and n̂ is the outward normal.

Choose as S a sphere of radius a ≫ R concentric with the metal sphere.  
Because of linear superposition the electric field everywhere outside the conductor can be written as

  **E** = **E0** + **EQ**,                        (2)

where

• **E0** is the original uniform field (magnitude E0, direction ẑ);  
• **EQ** is the field produced by the free charge Q that now sits on the conductor.  
 At large distance  

  **EQ**(r) = ( Q /4π ε r² ) r̂.                   (3)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Evaluate the force integral

Insert (2) into (1).  Because T is quadratic in **E**, three kinds of terms appear:

  T = T0 + TQ + Tc,

with  
T0 ∝ **E0**², TQ ∝ **EQ**², Tc ∝ **E0****EQ** (the “cross’’ term).

• T0 part: the stress generated by a purely uniform field is itself uniform; the integral of a constant pressure over a closed surface is zero, so it gives no net force.  

• TQ part: originates from a spherically‐symmetric Coulomb field; its contributions cancel by symmetry and give no net force either.

Therefore the entire force comes from the cross term Tc.

Write Tc explicitly,

  Tc = ε [ **E0****EQ** + **EQ****E0** – ( **E0**·**EQ** ) I ].

Contract Tc with n̂ = r̂ (because S is a sphere) to get the surface force density

  **f** ≡ Tc·n̂ = ε [ **E0** ( **EQ**·r̂ ) + **EQ** ( **E0**·r̂ )
                                  – ( **E0**·**EQ** ) r̂ ].        (4)

At the chosen surface r = a we have

  **EQ** = k r̂, with k = Q /4π ε a²,  
  **E0**·r̂ = E0 cosθ,  **EQ**·r̂ = k,  **E0**·**EQ** = E0 k cosθ.

Insert these relations into (4):

  **f** = ε [ **E0** k + k r̂ E0 cosθ – k E0 cosθ r̂ ] = ε k **E0**.     (5)

Remarkably, all θ–dependent pieces cancel; **f** is uniform over the integrating surface and is parallel to **E0**.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Integrate over the spherical surface

Because **f** is constant,

  **F** = ∮S **f** dS = ε k **E0** ∮S dS = ε k **E0** (4π a²).       (6)

Insert k,

  ε k (4π a²) = ε ( Q /4π ε a² ) (4π a²) = Q.

Thus

  **F** = Q **E0**.                                             (7)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Discussion

1.  Magnitude: F = |Q| E0.  
2.  Direction: parallel to the external field **E0**; along **E0** for Q > 0, opposite for Q < 0.  
3.  Independence of εr: the dielectric constant drops out entirely.  
 This happens because the bound surface charge created at the metal–dielectric interface, together with the surrounding polarized liquid, produces no net additional force in a perfectly uniform background field.  Only the free charge Q “feels’’ the uniform field.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,F \;=\; Q\,E_{0}\,}
\]

questions:
Given a particle with charge $q$ and mass $m$ moving in an electric field $\pmb{E}=E_{x}\pmb{x}+E_{z}\pmb{z}$ and a magnetic field $\pmb{B}=B\pmb{z}$. The initial conditions are: position $(x_{0},y_{0},z_{0})$ and velocity $(v_{\perp}\cos\delta,v_{\perp}\sin\delta,v_{z})$.

We know that a particle in a uniform magnetic field undergoes circular Larmor gyration, and the center of this rotation is called the guiding center. The drift velocity of this guiding center due to the electric field can be expressed using $\pmb{E},\pmb{B}$ and their magnitudes.

Problem: We discuss the case where the magnetic field is uniform, but the electric field is non-uniform. For simplicity, we assume $\pmb{E}$ is in the $\pmb{x}$ direction and varies sinusoidally in the $\pmb{y}$ direction.

$$
\pmb{E} \equiv E_{0}\cos(k y)\hat{\pmb{x}}
$$

In reality, such a charge distribution can occur in a plasma during wave propagation. Find the corresponding guiding center drift velocity. It is known that the electric field is very weak, and the particle's initial position is $(x_{0},y_{0},z_{0})$. Approximate to the lowest order that can distinguish from the uniform electric field case.
solutions:
This problem has been modified; the original problem had four questions.

If there is an electric field present, we find that the motion of the particle will be a combination of two movements: the normal circular Larmor gyration and a drift towards the center of guidance. We can choose the $\pmb{x}$ axis along the direction of $\pmb{E}$, so $\pmb{E}_{y}=0$, and the velocity components related to transverse components can be treated separately. The equation of motion is  

$$
m{\frac{d v}{d t}}=q({\pmb{E}}+v\times{\pmb{B}})
$$  

Its $\pmb{z}$ component is  

$$
\frac{d v_{z}}{d t}=\frac{q}{m}E_{z}
$$  

Integrating yields  

$$
v_{\tau}=\frac{q E_{z}}{m}t+v_{z0}
$$  

This is a simple motion along the direction of $\pmb{B}$. The transverse components of the previous equation are  

$$
\frac{d\upsilon_{x}}{d t}=\frac{q}{m}E_{x}\pm\omega_{c}\upsilon_{y}
$$  

$$
\frac{d\upsilon_{y}}{d t}=0\pm\omega_{c}\upsilon_{x}
$$  

where $\omega_{c}\equiv{\frac{|g|B}{m}}$ is the Larmor gyration angular frequency. Differentiating these two equations gives  

$$
\ddot{v}_{x}=-\omega_{c}^{2}v_{x}
$$  

$$
\ddot{v}_{y}=-\omega_{c}^{2}(v_{y}+\frac{E_{x}}{B})
$$  

We can rewrite the above equations as  

$$
\frac{d^{2}}{d t^{2}}(v_{y}+\frac{E_{x}}{B})=-\omega_{c}^{2}(v_{y}+\frac{E_{x}}{B})
$$  

Therefore, if we use $\begin{array}{r}{v_{y}+\frac{E_{x}}{B}}\end{array}$ instead of ${\pmb v_{\pmb y}}$, the equation simplifies to the situation when the electric field is zero. Thus, the two equations can be replaced by  

$$
v_{x}=v_{\perp}e^{i(\omega_{\mathrm{e}}t+\delta)}
$$  

$$
\upsilon_{y}=-i\upsilon_{\perp}e^{i(\omega_{c}t+\delta)}-\frac{E_{x}}{B}
$$  

where $\delta$ is the angle between the component of the particle's initial velocity in the $_{xy}$ plane ${\pmb v}_{\bot}$ and the $\pmb{x}$ axis (counter-clockwise direction). Further integration and taking the real part yields the equations of motion  

$$
x=x_{0}+\frac{v_{\perp}}{\omega_{c}}\sin(\omega_{c}t+\delta)
$$  

$$
y=y_{0}-\frac{E_{x}}{B}t+\frac{v_{\perp}}{\omega_{c}}[1-\cos(\omega_{c}t+\delta)]
$$  

$$
z=\frac{q E_{z}}{2m}t^{2}+v_{z0}t+z_{0}
$$  

From the equations of motion, it is observed that the Larmor motion of the particle is identical to the case without an electric field, but there is a drift superimposed in the $-y$ direction towards the center of guidance ${\pmb v}_{{\pmb g}{\pmb c}}$ (for $E_{z}>0)$.

To obtain the general formula for ${\pmb v}_{{\pmb g}{\pmb c}}$, we can solve the equation (1) using vector form. Since we already know that the term $\textstyle m{\frac{d v}{d t}}$ only gives rise to circular motion with frequency $\omega_{c}$, this term can be ignored in equation (1). Thus, equation (1) becomes  

$$
\pmb{{ E}}+\pmb{{\upsilon}}\times\pmb{{ B}}=0
$$  

By taking the cross product of $\pmb{B}$ with the above expression, we get  

$$
\pmb{E}\times\pmb{B}=\pmb{B}\times(\pmb{v}\times\pmb{B})=\pmb{v}\pmb{B}^{2}-\pmb{B}(\pmb{v}\cdot\pmb{B})
$$  

The transverse component of this equation is  

$$
v_{\perp q c}=E\times B/B^{2}\equiv v_{E}
$$  

We define this transverse component as $\pmb{v}_{E}$, which is the electric field drift towards the center of guidance.

The equation of motion for the particle is  

$$
m{\frac{d{\boldsymbol{v}}}{d t}}=q[{\boldsymbol{E}}({\boldsymbol{y}})+{\boldsymbol{v}}\times{\boldsymbol{B}}]
$$  

Decomposing into scalar form, we have  

$$
\dot{v}_{x}=\frac{q B}{m}v_{y}+\frac{q}{m}E_{x}(y)
$$  

$$
\dot{v}_{y}=-\frac{q B}{m}v_{x}
$$  

Simplifying yields  

$$
\ddot{\upsilon}_{x}=-\omega_{c}^{2}\upsilon_{x}\pm\omega_{c}\frac{\dot{E}_{x}(y)}{B}
$$  

$$
\ddot{v}_{y}=-\omega_{c}^{2}v_{y}-\omega_{c}^{2}\frac{E_{x}(y)}{B}
$$  

Here, $\pmb{E_{x}}(\pmb{y})$ is the electric field at the particle's location. To compute this value, we need to know the particle's trajectory, which is precisely what we attempt to solve initially. If the electric field is weak, as a first approximation, we can estimate $E_{x}(y)$ using the undisturbed trajectory.

The trajectory in the absence of an electric field is given by  

$$
y=y_{0}\pm r_{L}\cos\omega_{c}t
$$  

where $\begin{array}{r}{r_{L}=\frac{m v_{\perp}}{|q|B}}\end{array}$ is the Larmor gyration radius, and we obtain  

$$
\ddot{v}_{y}=-\omega_{c}^{2}v_{y}-\omega_{c}^{2}\frac{E_{0}}{B}\cos k(y_{0}\pm r_{L}\cos\omega_{c}t)
$$  

We seek a solution that is the sum of the gyration at $\omega_{c}$ and a stationary drift $_{v_{E}}$. Since we are interested in expressing $v_{E}$, we can average over one cycle to eliminate the gyration motion. Thus, the equation yields  

$$
\bar{v}_{x}=0
$$  

In the above equation, the average of the oscillating term $\ddot{v}_{y}$ is clearly zero, giving us  

$$
\overline{{\ddot{v}}}_{y}=0=-\omega_{c}^{2}\overline{{v}}_{y}-\omega_{c}^{2}\frac{E_{0}}{B}\overline{{\cos k(y_{0}\pm r_{L}\cos\omega_{c}t)}}
$$  

Upon expanding the small approximation and averaging, we find  

$$
\overline{{v}}_{y}=-\frac{E_{x}(y_{0})}{B}(1-\frac{1}{4}k^{2}r_{L}^{2})
$$  

Thus, due to non-uniformity, the usual $\pmb{{E}}\times\pmb{{B}}$ drift is modified to  

$$
\boxed{v_{E}={\frac{E\times B}{B^{2}}}(1-{\frac{1}{4}}{(k \frac{m v_{\perp}}{\vert{q}\vert B})}^2)}
$$  

The correction term represents the finite Larmor radius effect under the sinusoidal electric field distribution.
improved_solutions:
Solution Outline  
1.  Write down the exact (un‐perturbed) particle motion in the uniform magnetic field, introduce the gyro–radius ρ and the gyro–phase φ.  
2.  Express the electric field sampled by the particle along its Larmor orbit.  
3.  Average the usual E × B drift over one gyro–period to obtain the guiding–centre (g.c.) velocity.  
4.  Expand the result for small parameter kρ (weak, slowly varying field) and keep the first term that differs from the uniform–E case.

Details  

1.  Unperturbed Larmor motion in B = B ẑ  

Cyclotron (Larmor) frequency Ω ≡ qB/m .  
For a particle whose perpendicular speed is v⊥,

ρ ≡ v_\perp / Ω                                           (1)

is the Larmor radius.  
Taking the guiding–centre (x_c , y_c , z_c ) as the centre of the circle, the instantaneous position is

x(t)=x_c+ρ cosφ(t), y(t)=y_c+ρ sinφ(t), φ(t)=Ωt+φ_0 .     (2)

2.  Electric field seen along the orbit  

E_x(y)=E_0 cos(ky).                                        (3)

Substituting the y–coordinate of (2):

E_x(φ)=E_0 cos[k(y_c+ρ sinφ)].                             (4)

3.  Guiding–centre E × B drift  

For any instantaneous position the usual cross–field drift is

v_E(φ)=\frac{\mathbf E(φ)\times\mathbf B}{B^2}
      = -\frac{E_x(φ)}{B}\, \hat{\mathbf y}.                 (5)

The guiding–centre drift velocity is the gyro–average

v_gc = \langle v_E(φ)\rangle_{φ}= -\frac{1}{B}\,
        \langle E_x(φ)\rangle_{φ}\;
        \hat{\mathbf y}.                                     (6)

The required average is

⟨E_x(φ)⟩ = E_0 ⟨cos[k(y_c+ρ sinφ)]⟩_{φ}
         = E_0 cos(ky_c) ⟨cos(kρ sinφ)⟩_{φ}.                 (7)

Using the Bessel–function identity  

⟨cos(kρ sinφ)⟩_{φ}=J_0(kρ) ,                                 (8)

we obtain

v_gc = -\frac{E_0}{B} J_0(kρ)\,{\cos(ky_c)}\,
        \hat{\mathbf y}.                                    (9)

Equation (9) is the exact lowest–order guiding–centre drift (time–independent, i.e. no polarisation drift is produced because ∂E/∂t=0).  
For a strictly uniform electric field one would have the factor J_0≡1; hence the Bessel function encodes the finite Larmor–radius (FLR) correction due to the spatial variation of E.

4.  Expansion for small kρ  

Because the given wave field is stated to be “very weak”, we assume the scale length 1/k is large compared with ρ, so kρ≪1.  
Expanding J_0:

J_0(kρ)=1-\frac{(kρ)^2}{4}+O((kρ)^4).                       (10)

Insert (10) into (9):

v_gc ≃ -\frac{E_0}{B}\Bigl[1-\frac{(kρ)^2}{4}\Bigr]
       \cos(ky_c)\,\hat{\mathbf y}+O((kρ)^4).              (11)

The term −(kρ)^2/4 is the leading FLR correction; it is the first contribution that distinguishes the non–uniform-E case from the uniform one.

Summary  

Guiding–centre drift velocity in the presence of B = B ẑ and E = E_0 cos(ky) ẑₓ:

v_gc = -\dfrac{E_0}{B}\,J_0(k\rho)\cos(ky_c)\,\hat{\mathbf y}.  

To the lowest order that differs from the uniform-E result (kρ≪1):

v_gc ≃ -\dfrac{E_0}{B}\Bigl[1-\dfrac{(k\rho)^2}{4}\Bigr]
       \cos(ky_c)\,\hat{\mathbf y}.  

Here ρ = v_\perp/Ω with Ω = qB/m and y_c ≈ y_0 is the initial guiding–centre y–coordinate.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\mathbf v_{gc}\;=\;-\frac{E_0}{B}\,J_0(k\rho)\,\cos(ky_c)\;\hat{\mathbf y}
\;\;\simeq\;-\frac{E_0}{B}\Bigl[1-\frac{(k\rho)^2}{4}\Bigr]\cos(ky_c)\;\hat{\mathbf y}}
\]

questions: In the inertial frame \(S\), at time \(t = 0\), four particles simultaneously start from the origin and move in the directions of \(+x, -x, +y, -y\), respectively, with velocity \(v\). Consider another inertial frame \(S'\), which moves relative to \(S\) along the positive x-axis with velocity \(u\). At the initial moment, the two reference frames satisfy \(t = t' = 0\), where \(t'\) represents the time in the \(S'\) reference frame, and at the initial moment, the origins of the two reference frames coincide. Derive the relationship between the area of the quadrilateral formed by connecting the four particles in reference frame \(S'\) and time \(t'\). Consider the effects of special relativity, with the speed of light given as \(c\).
solutions:
In the inertial frame \( S \), four particles start from the origin at \( t = 0 \), moving with velocity \( v \) in the \( +x, -x, +y, -y \) directions, respectively. Another inertial frame \( S' \) moves relative to \( S \) in the positive \( x \)-direction with velocity \( u \). At the initial moment, the origins of the two reference frames coincide, and their clocks are synchronized. We need to find the relationship between the area of the quadrilateral formed by connecting the four particles' positions and time \( t' \) in frame \( S' \), taking into account relativistic effects as per special relativity.

---

1. **Lorentz Transformation**:
   - The coordinate transformation equations:
     \[
     x' = \gamma \left( x - ut \right), \quad t' = \gamma \left( t - \frac{ux}{c^2} \right)
     \]
     where \( \gamma = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - u^2/c^2}} \).

---

2. **Coordinate Transformation of Particles**:
   - **Particle 1 (in the \( +x \) direction)**:
     \[
     x_1' = \gamma \frac{(v - u)t}{1 - uv/c^2}, \quad y_1' = 0
     \]
     Time \( t_1' = \gamma t \left(1 - \frac{uv}{c^2}\right) \)

   - **Particle 2 (in the \( -x \) direction)**:
     \[
     x_2' = \gamma \frac{-(v + u)t}{1 + uv/c^2}, \quad y_2' = 0
     \]
     Time \( t_2' = \gamma t \left(1 + \frac{uv}{c^2}\right) \)

   - **Particle 3 (in the \( +y \) direction)**:
     \[
     x_3' = -\gamma ut, \quad y_3' = \frac{vt}{\gamma}
     \]
     Time \( t_3' = \gamma t \)

   - **Particle 4 (in the \( -y \) direction)**:
     \[
     x_4' = -\gamma ut, \quad y_4' = -\frac{vt}{\gamma}
     \]
     Time \( t_4' = \gamma t \)

---

3. **Coordinates at the Same Time \( t' \)**:
   - Coordinates of Particle 1 at time \( t' \) in frame \( S' \):
     \[
     x_1' = \frac{(v - u)t'}{1 - uv/c^2}, \quad y_1' = 0
     \]

   - Coordinates of Particle 2 at time \( t' \) in frame \( S' \):
     \[
     x_2' = \frac{-(v + u)t'}{1 + uv/c^2}, \quad y_2' = 0
     \]

   - Coordinates of Particles 3 and 4 at time \( t' \) in frame \( S' \):
     \[
     x_3' = -ut', \quad y_3' = \frac{vt'}{\gamma}
     \]
     \[
     x_4' = -ut', \quad y_4' = -\frac{vt'}{\gamma}
     \]

---

4. **Calculation of the Area**:
   - Coordinates of the four vertices of the quadrilateral:
     - \( A \left( \frac{(v - u)t'}{1 - uv/c^2}, 0 \right) \)
     - \( B \left( -ut', \frac{vt'}{\gamma} \right) \)
     - \( C \left( -ut', -\frac{vt'}{\gamma} \right) \)
     - \( D \left( \frac{-(v + u)t'}{1 + uv/c^2}, 0 \right) \)

   - Length of the base (distance from \( A \) to \( D \)):
     \[
     \text{Base} = \left| \frac{(v - u)t'}{1 - uv/c^2} - \frac{-(v + u)t'}{1 + uv/c^2} \right| = 2vt' \frac{(1 - u^2/c^2)}{1 - (uv/c)^2}
     \]

   - Height (distance from \( B \) to the \( x \)-axis):
     \[
     \text{Height} = \frac{vt'}{\gamma}
     \]

   - Area formula:
     \[
     \text{Area} = \text{Base} \times \text{Height} = 2vt' \frac{(1 - u^2/c^2)}{1 - (uv/c)^2} \times \frac{vt'}{\gamma}
     \]
     Substituting \( \gamma = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - u^2/c^2}} \) and simplifying:
     \[
     \text{Area} = \frac{2v^2 t'^2 (1 - u^2/c^2)^{3/2}}{1 - (uv/c)^2}
     \]

Derivation

   Frame S′ moves with speed u along +x of S.  
   Using β = u/c , γ ≡ 1/√(1−β²)

   t′ = γ ( t − u x/c² ) , x′ = γ ( x − u t ) , y′ = y                (2)

3. “Same-time” condition in S′  
   For every particle impose t′ = constant (the same clock reading in S′) and
   solve (2) for t.

   a) Particle P₊ˣ   (x = v t)  
      t′ = γ t (1 − uv/c²)  ⇒  t = t′ /[ γ (1−uv/c²) ]               (3a)

   b) Particle P₋ˣ   (x = −v t)  
      t′ = γ t (1 + uv/c²)  ⇒  t = t′ /[ γ (1+uv/c²) ]               (3b)

   c) Particles P₊ʸ , P₋ʸ  (x = 0)  
      t′ = γ t               ⇒  t = t′ /γ                           (3c)

4. Coordinates of the four particles at the same S′-time t′

   • P₊ˣ :  
        x′₁ = γ(v−u) t = t′ (v−u)/(1−uv/c²) ,  y′₁ = 0

   • P₋ˣ :  
        x′₂ = γ(−v−u) t = −t′ (v+u)/(1+uv/c²) ,  y′₂ = 0

   • P₊ʸ :  
        x′₃ = −u t′ ,  y′₃ =  v t′/γ

   • P₋ʸ :  
        x′₄ = −u t′ ,  y′₄ = −v t′/γ                                 (4)

   Thus the vertices of the quadrilateral in counter-clockwise order may be
   taken as  
   P₁(x′₁,0) → P₃(x′₃,y′₃) → P₂(x′₂,0) → P₄(x′₄,y′₄).

5. Area in S′ (shoelace formula)

   For four vertices (xᵢ,yᵢ), i=1…4,

   A = ½ | Σ xᵢ yᵢ₊₁ − yᵢ xᵢ₊₁ | (with 5≡1).                      (5)

   Plugging (4) and keeping the above order,

   Σ xᵢ yᵢ₊₁ − yᵢ xᵢ₊₁  
     = x′₁ y′₃ − y′₃ x′₂ + x′₂ y′₄ − y′₄ x′₁

   A = (v t′/γ) (x′₁ − x′₂).                                         (7)

6. Evaluate (x′₁ − x′₂)

   x′₁ − x′₂ = t′ [ (v−u)/(1−uv/c²) + (v+u)/(1+uv/c²) ]
             = t′ 2v (1−u²/c²) / (1−u²v²/c⁴).                        (8)

7. Final expression for the area

   Insert (8) into (7) and use γ = 1/√(1−u²/c²):

   A(t′) = 2 v² t′² (1−u²/c²)^{3/2} / (1−u² v² / c⁴).                (9)

   In terms of β_u = u/c and β_v = v/c,

   A(t′) = [2 v² t′²] / [ γ³ (1 − β_u² β_v² ) ], γ = 1/√(1−β_u²).   (10)

     relativistic factor γ³ and further modified by the angular-dependent
     denominator (1−β_u²β_v²).

\[
